user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
     * note that because pthread_cond_wait is a cancellation point, this needs to
     * employ the same protection that is in the binsem module.  In the event that
     * the thread is canceled inside pthread_cond_wait, the mutex will be re-acquired
     * before the cancellation occurs, leaving the mutex in a locked state.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_wait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CondVarWait_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static void OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The pthread_cleanup_push macro typically expands to a do { ... } while (0) idiom (an essentially Boolean integer-constant expression evaluating to false), which is explicitly permitted by MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 exception 2. This call therefore does not violate the rule. (It would only be a violation if the macro expansion introduced an invariant controlling expression that is not one of the permitted forms — e.g. an ordinary while(0) or for(;0;) loop — but that is not the usual/expected expansion.)
